{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3381649,"name":"Mr. Steele","username":"Omuzder","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/omuzder/{size}/154171_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-08T00:40:40.338Z","cooked":"

Hi CD, hoping to find some help or advice. 9062 is a younger team with a developing budget – meaning we have 5 swerve modules total. I’d like to find or make a holonomic drop-in substitute for swerve, so that we can continue to use our robots for outreach while developing our competition robots in parallel.

I’m not sure which method we should use, but here’s what I’m thinking and I’d appreciate any pointers.

  • either mecanum or omni wheels
  • 4 cim style motors
  • bolts in place of SDS modules
  • limited machining needed to make

Does anyone know of a design that’s already out there, or has anyone tried this before? If the answer’s no, 9062 can provide updates if/when we go through with this idea.

I haven’t seen anything like that, largely because the chassis setup for each is so different and nobody is looking to roll backwards for competition duty.

But for non-competition duty, I’d engineer something around the AndyMark Toughbox Micro, whatever 4" omni or mecanum wheels I was running, and some custom mounting plates to tie it all together. The TB Micro uses the same guts (shafts, gears, bearings) as the Toughbox Mini that has been in the KoP for a decade plus, so if you can raid a stockpile of old parts you can do it relatively cheaply.

A kiwi drive with a minicim and small andymark gearbox sounds like a good way forward as long as there is space. I would shy away from planetary gearboxes because of the small gears inside.

A setup like this woud only really require a custom plate and some aluminum angle to mount the plate to the frame.

You would retain full movement capabilities with the drawback of limited pushing power on a flat field. If you anticipate terrain or bumps like a 2023 cable protector you may want to look at a different solution as omni wheels at a 45° angle are ill suited for hitting obstacles.

Thank you for the info, I have seen the micros floating around for a while now. Might be worth picking up.

Would Vex clamping gearboxes work in this case, similarly to the micros? We have some in our lab already.

FYI Max plantarys seem fine(I know I saw a picture of one a team used for an offseason event last year).

One perspective to add: Do you need a drivetrain that drives? That is the simplest answer to the problem that requires the least amount of work. From my eperece at outreach events having a student push or kick a game piece into the intake works well and you don’t need a moving robot. You do lose some of the interaction of chasing after kids but that is probably for the better

I know of one design that used lazer cut plywood and passive omni wheels to mock the location and hight of the swerve modules. We made something similar with large caster wheels but we forgot about wheel clearance.

Omuzder:

Would Vex clamping gearboxes work in this case, similarly to the micros? We have some in our lab already.

Same concept, and probably simpler if the ratio works. (My team hasn’t ordered anything from VEX in years, so it’s out of my brain.)

Skyehawk:

I would shy away from planetary gearboxes because of the small gears inside.

I wouldn’t rule out a MAXPlanetary on it, especially if the other end of the shaft is supported. 57 Sport would definitely need the other end supported, but on a light robot it might be in range. VersaPlanetary, yeah agreed no. But in all cases, packaging on it relatively to the rest of the robot would be the question.
